name: Poincaré Conjecture (SOLVED)
latex: \text{Every simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to the 3-sphere}
explanation: Henri Poincaré's 1904 conjecture was one of the most famous problems in topology. It asks whether a 3-dimensional space with no holes (simply connected) that is finite and has no boundary must be equivalent to a 3-sphere. This was one of the seven Millennium Prize Problems. In 2002-2003, Grigori Perelman proved it using Ricci flow, but declined the $1 million prize. This was the first Millennium Prize Problem to be solved.

examples.solution: That any 3-dimensional space without holes that is finite and closed must be topologically equivalent to a 3-sphere
steps: Poincaré asked: How do you tell if a 3D space is a sphere?
In 2D, a circle is the only simply connected closed surface
In 3D, the answer was unknown for 100 years
Perelman used Ricci flow to prove it's the 3-sphere

examples.problem: Why did Perelman decline the prize?
examples.solution: He declined both the Fields Medal and Millennium Prize, saying the proof was more important than recognition
steps: He said 'I'm not interested in money or fame'

proof: Status: SOLVED (2003) by Grigori Perelman using Ricci flow. Perelman declined the $1 million Millennium Prize. The proof is considered one of the greatest mathematical achievements of the 21st century.
